ctaText2: a deeper, expanded version of the key takeaways

slides.title: 1. Become genuinely interested in other people
slides.body:
The most successful networkers focus on others,
not on themselves.

Ask about people's lives, listen carefully,
remember small details.

Genuine interest is felt and returned.

slides.title: 2. Smile and use people's names
slides.body:
A **smile** is a universal signal of friendliness.

A person's **name** is the most important sound
in any language for that person.

Using it shows respect and makes the interaction personal.

slides.title: 3. Be a good listener—encourage others to talk about themselves
slides.body:
People love to talk about what matters to them.

You can create connection by:
• asking open-ended questions
• waiting patiently for the answer
• reflecting back what you heard

Listening actively builds instant rapport.

slides.title: 4. Talk in terms of the other person's interests
slides.body:
Find out what the other person cares about
and steer the conversation there.

Even if you do not share the interest,
showing curiosity makes your contribution
more engaging and relevant.

slides.title: 5. Avoid criticism, condemnation and complaint
slides.body:
Negative language puts people on the defensive.

Carnegie's rule:
**never criticize—use appreciation and gentle correction instead.**

This preserves goodwill and makes change more likely.

slides.title: 6. Admit your mistakes quickly and clearly
slides.body:
Owning your errors defuses conflict.

A simple admission:
"I was wrong about this, and I appreciate your patience."

It shows humility and encourages others
to be less defensive.

slides.title: 7. Begin with honest praise before giving negative feedback
slides.body:
When you need to correct, start with something real you admire.

Then:
• point to a specific behavior
• explain the impact
• express confidence in improvement

Feedback framed this way is easier to accept.

slides.title: 8. Let others feel the idea is theirs
slides.body:
People support what they co-create.

You can:
• ask questions that guide them toward your conclusion
• build on their suggestions
• credit them for good points you use

You influence by planting ideas,
not by forcing them.
